# Analyze the uploaded site files for quick perf-relevant stats
import os, gzip, io, re, json

base = "/mnt/data"
files = ["index.html", "tuition-css-1.0.0.css"]

rows = []
for fn in files:
    p = os.path.join(base, fn)
    with open(p, "rb") as f:
        data = f.read()
    size = len(data)
    gz = gzip.compress(data, compresslevel=9)
    gz_size = len(gz)
    try:
        import brotli
        br_size = len(brotli.compress(data, quality=11))
    except Exception as e:
        br_size = None
    rows.append({
        "file": fn,
        "raw_bytes": size,
        "gzip_bytes(level9)": gz_size,
        "brotli_bytes(q11)": br_size
    })

# Parse index.html for quick heuristics
with open(os.path.join(base, "index.html"), "r", encoding="utf-8") as f:
    html = f.read()

img_tags = re.findall(r"<img\b", html, re.I)
loading_lazy = re.findall(r'loading\s*=\s*"lazy"', html, re.I)
fetchpriority_high = re.findall(r'fetchpriority\s*=\s*"high"', html, re.I)
preconnects = re.findall(r'<link\s+[^>]*rel\s*=\s*"preconnect"[^>]*>', html, re.I)
preloads = re.findall(r'<link\s+[^>]*rel\s*=\s*"preload"[^>]*>', html, re.I)
scripts = re.findall(r"<script\b", html, re.I)

external_hosts = re.findall(r'https?://([^/"\'>]+)', html, re.I)
external_hosts = list(dict.fromkeys(external_hosts))  # de-dup preserving order

summary = {
    "counts": {
        "img_tags": len(img_tags),
        "img_loading_lazy": len(loading_lazy),
        "img_fetchpriority_high": len(fetchpriority_high),
        "link_preconnects": len(preconnects),
        "link_preloads": len(preloads),
        "script_tags": len(scripts),
        "unique_external_hosts": len(external_hosts)
    },
    "external_hosts": external_hosts
}

import pandas as pd
from caas_jupyter_tools import display_dataframe_to_user

df_sizes = pd.DataFrame(rows)
display_dataframe_to_user("Site asset compression sizes", df_sizes)

df_summary = pd.DataFrame([summary["counts"]])
display_dataframe_to_user("HTML quick metrics", df_summary)

# Also show external hosts list as a small dataframe
df_hosts = pd.DataFrame({"external_hosts": external_hosts})
display_dataframe_to_user("Unique external hosts referenced in HTML", df_hosts)

print("Computed file metrics and HTML summary. You can scroll the tables above for details.")

parts: Great ask. I did a quick, objective speed audit of the two files you shared and surfaced the highest-impact fixes first. I also ran a local analysis to quantify some basics; you’ll see three small tables pinned above (file sizes, HTML metrics, and external hosts). # TL;DR (prioritized) 1) **Images** (LCP + total bytes): ship AVIF/WebP sources for hero + section images; keep JPG as fallback. 2) **3rd-party** (variance): tame Google Tag Manager’s early network work; trim preconnects. 3) **Logos & icons** (requests): stop loading both light/dark logos; replace PNG checkmarks with a 0-request SVG. 4) **Caching & compression** (repeat visits): assert Brotli + far-future cache in `.htaccess`. 5) **Minor polish**: refine the JSON preload, add idle prefetch of likely next pages, and put a floor under the testimonial carousel height. --- ## What’s already strong - **Clean critical path**: one CSS file, one LCP hero image, minimal synchronous JS; CSS is defer-friendly and sections use `content-visibility: auto` to punt layout/paint offscreen. fileciteturn0file1 - **Mobile-first image policy** throughout (small default, big only ≥1440px) plus `loading="lazy"` on non-hero images. fileciteturn0file0 - **Priority hints** on the LCP hero (`fetchpriority="high"`) and an ahead-of-time preload for the desktop hero candidate. fileciteturn0file0 --- ## High-impact fixes ### 1) Ship modern image formats (LCP + bandwidth) Keep your `` structure but add AVIF/WebP sources so modern browsers fetch ~30–60% fewer bytes for the exact same pixels. Example for the **hero** (preserve your current sizing/priority): ```html ``` Repeat this pattern for *about/qualifications/programs* images (keep your current `sizes` and lazy-loading). fileciteturn0file0 > Note: avoid preloading **and** `fetchpriority="high"` for the same candidate; keep just one high-priority signal per viewport to prevent starvation. You’re currently preloading only the ≥1440px hero (good) and using `fetchpriority` on the default hero (also good). Don’t add another preload for the 768px source. fileciteturn0file0 ### 2) Constrain GTM’s early work + trim preconnects - GTM runs in the `` (as recommended), but it’s still the biggest source of variability because it can fan out to other tags. Consider **delaying container load** until `requestIdleCallback` or after the `load` event if you’re comfortable trading first-page analytics for speed on cold visits, or run **Consent Mode (denied by default)** so GTM avoids hitting `google-analytics.com` before interaction. fileciteturn0file0 - **Preconnects:** keep `googletagmanager.com` (used immediately) but **remove or downgrade** the others: - `google-analytics.com`: only needed if GTM actually loads GA early—otherwise switch to `dns-prefetch`. - `wa.me`: not used during initial render; drop preconnect (or use `dns-prefetch`). fileciteturn0file0 ### 3) Stop double-loading the logo; make the checkmark 0-request - You currently ship both **light and dark** logo PNGs in the DOM; browsers typically request both even if one is hidden. Switch to `` so only one is fetched: ```html ``` This replaces the two `` tags in your header. fileciteturn0file0 - Replace the hero list PNG checkmarks with an **inline SVG mask** to eliminate those requests: ```css .hero-bullets li::before{ content:""; width:1em;height:1em; background: currentColor; -webkit-mask: url('data:image/svg+xml;utf8,') no-repeat center/contain; mask: url('data:image/svg+xml;utf8,') no-repeat center/contain; } ``` (Your current CSS pulls `check-24.png` / `check-48.png` via `image-set`.) fileciteturn0file1 ### 4) Lock in Brotli + long-lived caching You’re already versioning assets via query strings (`?v=...`). Make sure the server actually **Brotli-compresses** HTML/CSS/JS and sets **far-future Cache-Control** on images/CSS/JS. Drop this into your site root `.htaccess` (adjust if some modules are unavailable): ```apache # --- Compression (prefer Brotli, fallback to gzip) BrotliCompressionQuality 6 AddOutputFilterByType BROTLI_COMPRESS text/html text/css application/javascript application/json image/svg+xml AddOutputFilterByType DEFLATE text/html text/css application/javascript application/json image/svg+xml # --- Caching: 1 year for static, 1 hour for HTML ExpiresActive On ExpiresByType text/html "access plus 1 hour" ExpiresByType text/css "access plus 1 year" ExpiresByType application/javascript "access plus 1 year" ExpiresByType image/avif "access plus 1 year" ExpiresByType image/webp "access plus 1 year" ExpiresByType image/jpeg "access plus 1 year" ExpiresByType image/png "access plus 1 year" ExpiresByType image/svg+xml "access plus 1 year" Header set Cache-Control "public, max-age=31536000, immutable" Header set Cache-Control "public, max-age=3600" ``` (Your CSS/JS already carry `?v=...`; that’s fine here.) fileciteturn0file0 --- ## Medium-impact & correctness - **Menu JSON preload:** you preload `assets/data/menu.json` as `fetch` with `crossorigin`. Because it’s same-origin and doesn’t need cookies, either **drop `crossorigin`** on the preload or explicitly fetch with `credentials: 'omit'` in JS so the request keys match and you get a true cache hit. Otherwise some browsers may double-fetch. fileciteturn0file0 - **Testimonials carousel CLS:** you animate the track height; set a **min-height** to the tallest expected card so the section doesn’t grow after data loads on slow devices: ```css .section--testimonials .t-viewport { min-height: 360px; } /* tune to your tallest */ ``` (You already wrap with a fixed viewport and transition height; this just removes residual layout shift on first render.) fileciteturn0file1 - **Next-page prefetch (on idle):** prefetch `junior-college-maths.html`, `secondary-school-maths.html`, and `university-maths.html` after the page is idle to make nav feel instant, but **skip on Save-Data**: ```html ``` - **Keep your current hero tuning:** You’ve already made the hero image fill its container with `object-fit: cover` and absolute positioning, and tightened vertical rhythm between **800–1199px**—that’s exactly what we’d do for LCP/CLS on tablets. fileciteturn0file1 --- ## Minor/nice-to-have - **System font stack:** you’re already on it—no webfonts = fewer requests. Keep it. fileciteturn0file1 - **Avoid redundant resource hints:** every hint is a TLS handshake; only keep preconnects for hosts contacted in the first second. `wa.me` is not; drop it. fileciteturn0file0 - **JS bundle:** your main JS is deferred; when convenient, ensure it’s minified/treeshaken and split if you add heavier features later. fileciteturn0file0 --- ## Verification (what to measure) Add real-user Web Vitals so you can verify improvements (LCP, CLS, INP). If you don’t want to touch GTM/GA yet, log to the console first: ```html ``` --- ## Why these changes - Your LCP is the hero image; modern codecs + one real preconnect + constrained GTM produce the biggest wins for the least complexity. fileciteturn0file0 - Eliminating duplicate logo fetches and PNG checkmarks removes avoidable requests while preserving your current design. fileciteturn0file0turn0file1 - Strong compression + caching turns repeat visits into “instant” without touching layout/UX. - The rest are micro-optimizations that keep you under budget on mid-range Android/3G. If you want, I can patch your header/logo snippet and the hero `` blocks directly in your HTML next.

def picture_summary(pic):
    info = {}
    img = pic.find('img')
    info['img_src'] = img.get('src') if img else None
    info['img_srcset'] = img.get('srcset') if img else None
    info['img_sizes'] = img.get('sizes') if img else None
    sources = []
    for source in pic.find_all('source'):
        sources.append({'media': source.get('media'), 'srcset': source.get('srcset')})
    info['sources'] = sources
    return info

parts: Short answer: **mostly yes, but not always only the smallest file.** Here’s what your current HTML actually does (I checked your uploaded `index.html`): - **Hero image** ```html ``` On phones and tablets (<1440 px), only the **768 px** image loads. The 1536 px asset is exposed **only** for ≥1440 px (and the preload is also media-gated), so you’re safe here. - **“About tutor” & “Qualifications” images** Same pattern: a `(min-width:1440px)` source (1200 px) and a single fallback (600 px). Phones load **600 px** only. - **Subject tiles (University / JC / Secondary)** ```html ``` Here, phones **do not always load only the 360 px** file. The browser picks based on `sizes × devicePixelRatio`. Examples with your exact `sizes`: - 360 px wide, **DPR 1** → target ≈ 302 px → **360w** chosen - 360 px wide, **DPR 2** → target ≈ 605 px → **720w** chosen - 390 px wide, **DPR 3** → target ≈ 983 px → **720w** chosen - 768 px wide tablet (≤899 rule → 400 px slot), DPR 2 → target 800 px → **720w** chosen So high-DPR phones and most tablets will legitimately choose **720w** (still not the 1080 desktop source). - **Logos** You have two separate `` tags (light + dark). Many browsers will fetch both regardless of theme. That’s not mobile-first. Use a `` with `prefers-color-scheme` so only one logo is requested. - **CSS icons** The hero checkmark uses `image-set(...)` with 1x/2x PNGs; high-DPR phones will pull the **48 px** variant. These are tiny and not a concern. --- ## Verdict - **Nothing** in your markup forces desktop-sized images onto phones. ✅ - But for the **subject tiles**, high-DPR mobiles will often select the **720w** variant. If your requirement is “**phones must always load the smallest**,” your current `srcset/sizes` logic intentionally *does not* do that (it favors sharpness). ## If you truly want “small only” on phones Use a `` media split that offers **only** the small asset to narrow viewports: ```html ``` That removes the browser’s freedom to up-select on DPR for phones. (Be aware this will look softer on 2×/3× devices—by design.) ## Quick win on the logos Replace the two ``s with: ```html ``` This prevents double-fetch on both mobile and desktop. If you’d like, I can patch the three subject `` blocks and the header logo in your HTML to enforce strict “small-only on phones” while keeping current behavior elsewhere.
If my mobile images are already in the 15-20KB range and the page as a whole uses only a several such images, is there any value in optimizing them any further?

thoughts.content: E-Jay is interested in whether further mobile image optimization is worth it given 15-20KB image sizes with a small number of images. In general, those sizes are already small. Switching formats like AVIF/WebP could help, but it's important to consider the trade-offs, like decode costs and memory usage. A noticeable improvement in LCP time from 20KB to 10KB is just a few milliseconds on 4G, so the benefits may be marginal. There are still reasons to optimize for modern formats where useful.

Decoding AVIF could cost more CPU than JPEG, and for icons, SVG might be better than PNG. The real push for optimization, though, comes from reducing requests and critical path blocking: preloading and caching play a big role. On 4G, 20KB's overhead is almost negligible, and further compression saves just a few milliseconds. For high-DPR displays, 20KB might compromise image sharpness. Offline AVIF/WebP conversion addresses optimization, though diminishing returns set in below 10KB due to header costs.

thoughts.summary: Optimizing for LCP and image performance
thoughts.content: With HTTP/2, there's still some overhead even though it's efficient. To optimize, aim for LCP image sizes under 50KB for mobile and under 20KB for sub-hero images. Focus on caching, responsive image selection, eliminating duplicate requests, and deferring non-critical images. For battery savings, balance encoding formats like MozJPEG or AVIF, considering decoder speeds. As for LCP, background images are now considered in LCP if loaded via CSS on block-level elements, which is a shift from before.

In 2024, background images loaded with `url()` are counted for LCP, but focusing on "waste elimination" is more important. If total image size is under 200-300KB, gains are minimal. Focus on caching, removing duplicate images, and avoiding irrelevant preconnects. Modern formats are useful, but re-encoding isn’t always worth the few KB saved. Ensure that image quality, especially for 360-600px JPEGs, doesn’t suffer, and consider using tools like SSIM for optimization.

parts:
Short answer: **probably not worth it**, unless you can do it *once* with near-zero effort (e.g., an auto-encoder in your build) or you have a lot of very slow-network users.

### Why
- **15–20 KB** per mobile image is already small. On a typical 4G link (≈10 Mbps), trimming **10 KB** saves ~**8 ms** of transfer time; even at 1 Mbps it’s ~**80 ms**. The dominant costs for first view are **RTT/TLS handshakes** and the **LCP hero fetch**, not squeezing a few more kilobytes out of already-small assets.
- You only have “several” images on the page, so total image budget is already modest. Diminishing returns kick in fast.

### When further optimization *is* still sensible
- **One-time format upgrade:** If it’s easy, convert JPGs to **AVIF/WebP** and serve via `<picture>` (keep JPG fallback). You’ll often cut 15–20 KB → 9–14 KB with no visual loss. Do it once; don’t hand-tune per file.
- **Data-saver users:** Add a `(prefers-reduced-data: reduce)` `<source>` that points to the small variant to *force* tiny images for those users.
- **Hero/LCP image only:** If any hero file is >~**50 KB** on mobile, it’s worth revisiting; that one asset can still move LCP.

### What will matter more than squeezing 2–5 KB
- **Eliminate duplicate fetches** (e.g., load only one logo via `<picture media="(prefers-color-scheme: …)">`).
- **Resource-hint hygiene** (keep only truly needed `preconnect`/`preload`; don’t double-signal priorities).
- **Caching & CDN** (Brotli + long-lived Cache-Control; optional CDN). This benefits every repeat view massively.
- **Correct `sizes/srcset`** so mobiles don’t up-select larger variants unnecessarily; clamp with media-split `<picture>` if you *must* force the smallest on phones.

### Decision rule of thumb
- **If total above-the-fold images ≤ ~150–200 KB and the mobile hero ≤ ~50 KB, stop micro-optimizing.** Spend effort on caching, duplicate request removal, priority ordering, and any 3rd-party tag discipline. That’s where the real wins are now.

If you want, I can revise your `<picture>` blocks to add AVIF/WebP once and wire in a reduced-data source—low effort, measurable upside, no ongoing maintenance.
